element_texts.text: Completed

Isaac, Du Quoin, Feb 15 1857                                                  
Elyria, Ohio     
Du Quoin, Perry Co.Illinois
Sabbath Afternoon, Feb. 15 1857

My Dear Ettie

                  Last night arrived your dear letter of the eighth; written part of it just one week ago today and mailed last Monday. You had just been hearing one of Mr Wilbers excellent sermons. I did not make out near as well as that that day. I wrote to you about the Sabbaths here.

Today it is far better. It is however a very rainy day; a really great rain indeed; but there were a dozen or more men out to hear Mr Post preach ~ no women however.
He preached almost without notes from "The Earth is full of the goodness of God". He quoted Lieut. Maury's "Physical Geography of the Sea" in relation to the influence of the Gulf Streams; also quoted Hugh Miller, & Barry's theory of the differences of nations on sides of East & West mountain ranges, & their homogeniety on sides of North & South ranges. Perhaps he started this theory rather more plainly than I have though. He made it all plain & applied it to the limited States, that God has written its history in the North & South mountains & rivers, as the greatest & richest & undivided of Nations.
Enlarging upon the prospects & duties of the people of this country; he finally came down to DuQuoin, its prospects, its people, and their duties.
He said it was probable that this would be the most important place in Southern Illinois ~probable ~almost certain ~ necessary ; and it behoved the good people now here, for the sake of themselves, their children, & their children's children, to put forth their energies now and start the right influences & institutions here now.
Completed

now, before the thousands of Miners, degraded ~ ignorant~sensual should outnumber out vote out influence there and this village. It was comparatively easy to start things right here now. What would it be when in a few years there were four or five thousand souls here. 
He said as the storm prevented others? he was talking only to menfolks; and he told them their duty pretty plainly I thought.
They must have cold times at Dunbarton this winter. I pity the old horse. Perhaps though your father allows him a blanket when it is so very cold. Are you not glad you live in a more genial climate? Do you not wish you lived still further south say here. I do think Ettie, that this right here is about the finest climate I have ever known anything about. It is incomparably so for nine months in the year say from Oct. 1st to June 1st, and usually perhaps half the rest of the time. There is one exception, though to the winter ~the mud, ~that however is probably no means as bad as in Ohio. There is nothing quite equal to the warm rich sunny haze of the winter days here. The New England Indian Summer weather is only an imitation of it. It is weather with which both 'Waubun' and Shawandasee' might be satisfied see Hiawatha.
Merrick Brigham at Bloomington. What is his business? Address &c.? I go to see him? Perhaps Uncle Elmer call at Elyria on his way out. Of course he can ~and must ~write and tell him so. Exactly on the main best through route. Great Lake Shore Line ~most convenient stopping place on it; through tickets ~stop over,
Completed

No sort of expense to stop, only the time ~ saving too to stop & rest on a long journey. Must stop, and undoubtedly will stop, at any rate. Write to him at once, please.
I would not be out of apples if you can get more. Doubtless you can at Austins, if no where else. They may cost more there ~but I would have them at any rate ~both on your own account and little Wilder's too.
So it seems you are getting a good deal, on considerable acquainted among the good folks of Elyria. How many calls have you made? "Evil communications corrupt good manners". My Sunday letter writing example contaminating you. I am sorry for your smitings of conscience; but decidedly glad of the letters not with standing. I guess the balance of good is on our side upon the whole
I do not want Wilder to forget me. I must go home on that account, even if I have to come out again very soon.
Money. I hope you have got some before this time. I mailed a Fifty dollar draft to on the 5th inst. and a hundred dollar check on the 9th inst. I presume you get them both in the course of last week. If not, write it, of course. 
I mailed a letter to you every day last week till yesterday I believe. Of course there could not be much in them. As a whole I judge they were not worth reading. If I had written only one in course of the week, as two last ones, they might be better worth reading. I undertook to write everyday in the week, being vexed at the mails because you did not get any letters for whole weeks I thought I would be sure to write often enough.
But Friday, working outdoors all day, I was so busy in office all evening, I omitted it,
Completed

There I have just written a letter to my Mother.
I have written to her twice before since I have been in Illinois. Do you suppose she will come out this Spring to Elyria? You and Anna must write to her to persuade her to do so, if you can. I guess she will. Samuel will try too to persuade her to come with him.
You speak of Jenny's Sabbaths Afternoon Bible Class. What is it? Is Mr Brooks the Teacher? Is he a good one? Is the class a good one? Who are they? Young Ladies? or Gentlemen & Ladies? Jenny does not go to the Sabbath School does she?
Mr Post preaches again this evening. It does not rain now, clears off just before night after a great rain and the whole country is almost under water. The whole Prairie looks afloat. But I guess I can get to the School house without going over the tops of my high boots.
When shall I get home? Well I do not know. I think I will get through here this week sometime, in the course of the week I am pretty certain. Then, I am undecided whether to go home or to Iowa. I want to go home, I do not know but I ought to go to Iowa.
Well good night & I go to Church. 
I thought I had finished this letter; but I have got back from meeting & find here is a little more room; I was late & meeting this morning almost half an hour early, R.R. Time. I intended to be in season; but  it is hard deciding upon the exact time of candle lighting. I like Mr Post, and wish he could preach here all the time. You could almost be amused at the contrast between him & Mr Wilbur. The idea of Mr Post, his gestures are all made with the closed fist. 
However I like him & think he is fitted to do good here. Quite an audience tonight, through mud and water. Your own Isaac
Completed

Elyria, Monday, 16 Feb, 1857
My dearest,
I believe I have had two letters from you since I wrote on Friday - one written the 4th the other the 6th. O the letters are such a comfort!
You speak of the Protest - Anna said that the Dr. had heard from Eliab, and that he sent money in season & the Express Co. lost it - and he had set them to work to hunt it up.
In that case, you will not have it to pay, will you? It is too bad altogether. We have a little mud here - it rained all night before last & all last night quite hard, and the the water stands all about. I must go today to Mr Crandell, and get him to come and put in a piece of the cistern conductor that tumbled out Saturday -
Completed

Those two rains have been lost to the lower cistern on that account.  The upper tank is half full about.   A dutchman came and took away twelve bushels of ashes Friday & Saturday - paid me six cents per bush.  Wanted to pay in tallow candles but I told him we did not burn them.  -  There were four stores burnt out at the fire - Clark - flour & feed  -
Neatfoot - furniture       Bullock - Hard Ware      Northrup & Hannan - ?Tinnan?   great sympathy for all but Neatfoot - He is rich, and beside did not lose anything - got all his furniture out - buildings belonged to Murry.   Northrup & Hannan lost $11.00   $700.00 Insured $400.00 worth of tools lost.  They young - just commencing.
Completed

Wilder does not feel very well these days - looks rather pale - his upper gums are very badly swelled indeed. He is kicking on the floor with his thumb in his mouth and the indispensable napkin in his little hand. Dear little one; he wants to go to sleep or to rest. Ive given him his kisses, and he kisses his mother very sweetly when he has a mind. Hattie & Libbie were both here after school Friday - ate doughnuts & gingerbread for lunch as they could not stay to supper - Anna does not love to have them come to dinner except when she tells them to. I imagine she will tell them today. It is so wet. I sent a Valentine to Libbie Saturday whereat she was greatly delighted.
Completed

Their mother sent them two apiece writing one set back handed. The others they laid to her charge at once but thought the back-handed ones from Jennie - and Hattie, with this impression, sent one to Jennie as a reply. Anna came over to tell Jennie to keep dark. I got baby a new pair of shoes Saturday - and we had some very nice steak for dinner that day & yesterday which I wish you could have help us eat. Two & a half lbs made us two meals & a hash. We have not been able to get chickens at all since you went away. The butcher says he does not have them at all. The kitchen wood holds out yet - but I expect I ought to be getting some sawed. 
Ann called for her clothes after 
text upside down Tell me what my error was in spelling, so I may not repeat it.
Completed

upper left corner -- page number 5
she had been gone about three weeks - wanted pay for the last two days she was here including washing. I had paid her up to last night & she left Monday night. I had not deducted for the four days absence because the smallest money I had then was a 2.00 bill, and I had no thought then of her not returning of course. I told I had already paid her for two days when she was gone and I could not give her anymore. Anna said I ought to have asked her to pay me back for the two days, but I thought it would be of no use and only make a fuss. She took the pillowcase that belonged in her room, when she went the Monday night to put some of her clothes in. I missed it & asked her when she called where it was. She told me she took it, &
Completed

forgot to bring it back - but would bring it the next week but she did not, and I presume never will. I am sorry, it breaks a pair. Elisabeth is very capable, so much neater than Ann. She has the reputation of being wilful not stopping long at a place. If anything does not suit her, she leaves - goes out - little and has little company. Wilder won't stay much long? with her. Mr. Robbins case was delayed from Wed. till Sat. - occupied afternoon & eve of sat. and Id not know yet the result or whether it was decided Mr.Robbins preached last Eve. Mr. Wilber seemed to have a cold affecting his voice some. Mr Robbins subject what is the ultimate end of mans existence and what the highest good to be attained - very good & interesting. Mrs Goodspeed & Mrs Cooley called saturday. O how we shall rejoice when you
Completed

can be with us again - the garden
will need somebody ere long if
this weather continues - But
I want you to stay till you are
through so you need not go
directly back.
Your prospects seem good regarding
the Du Quoin property - It is pleasant
to have enough for ourselves and
some to give away too.  But life
seems so frail a thing to me.  Even
I could not realize that our dear
little ones could die, but now when I 
look at little Wilder, I feel that he is
only lent.  I feel that he may die - We
may have other little ones to love, but
all may die - Still I know we ought
to prepare to live, as well as try to be
ready for death - Sad thoughts will come to me.
How many acres was your last purchase
& was it coal land, or only near the coal.
If I remember, that farm was higher land
than most about it.
Completed

Isaac Duquoin Feb. 20. 1857
Elyria Ohio                                                                                                   Du Quoin

                                                                                                                   Friday Evening Feb. 28 1857

Dearest
Last night I wrote you a letter, having
none to reply to.  Tonight I am more fortunate,
having just received yours of the 16th;
Seven nice pages from you, and two or three
from Jenny to God! I am very much
obliged to both of you therefore
you had received two letters from me those mailed
the 6th & 7th  The one with $100.00 Check had not
yet come to you.  I presume Eliab will
attend to the Protest matter.  It is nothing
serious in the end.
You have a little mud in Elyria!  Is it Possible?
We have a little here.  I do not know the exact depths.
The strata of 'dilurium' or 'drift' geologically speaking,
is here generally from 10 to 50 feet in
thickness, super imposed upon Lime stone; and
for practical purposes it would do very well to consider
it and the present mud as similar and
convertible terms.
It was really quite a fire for Elyria.  I am
sorry for Northup & Hannan?.  They were not able to
lose, and I like them first rate.
Completed

Tell Mrs De Witt that if she does not want her young
ladies to dine out without leave, that she
must give them leave.  Dinner
will not hurt school girls and if it is no better
than they can get at Aunt Netties.  One thing though
I should like to tell Anna she might direct the girls
not to eat cake at Aunt Nettie's or any where else.
that is, I would tell her so - if it were not
that you would all say it was only my "silly
prejudice against cake!'
Chickens - You could not get any.  It is very like
the butcher would not keep them  he prefers to sell
his meats.  The place to get chickens is at the
Stores, Starrs, or Knowleys'.
Your wrong spelling.  Did I not write you the word?
I have forgotten it now - entirely.  I was nothing.
I think you got off excellently well with Polly Ann
if you only overpaid her two days, and she carried off
only a pillow case.  It is certainly a very lucky
escape.  I hope the present Betsy will be better yet.
It seems a pity that she & Wilder do not agree
better.  But I would always hate to leave
a child much with any girl I was not fully
acquainted with.  The little child cannot
tell if it is abused, or if anything is wrong.
Geo. T. Wall, Abram Mitchell, C.A Keyes and
I.S. Metcalf bought of Hiram Pyle, Jan. 1857
50 1/2 acres of Prairie cultivated land at $50.00 per acre
Said land lies in the east side of the R.R Track and
Completed

adjoining the same, immediately north of Keyes & Metcalf's
village of DuQuoin.  It will sometime be all
laid out doubtless  and sold as village lots; and
it is also all of it undoubtedly Coal land.
The Ashley Coal Mines are one mile due North
of it.  The New "Tetley Coal Mine," the most favorable
opening yet made is just across the R.R track on
its S.W corner, on land sold by said R.& M for coal
mining purposes.  The New Mines to be opened this
spring, and for which I am just locating R.R Track
are just at its S.E corner.  The Frizzell Mine
very favorable worked on a small scale for a 
year past is half a mile S.E  Some coal has
been worked all along East & North East of it.
In short there is no land promises fairer as coal
land than does this.  In this regard it is a great
bargain.  But one year ago or less it was offered
at one half, viz $25.00 per acre.  Three years ago
I presume it could have been bought for about
one quarter, $12.50 per acre.  Five year ago for 
probably less than half of that.
Vancil the Landlord has just today sold
out the "DuQuoin House" for $2500.00
cost him in all about $1500.00 and he has 
made lots out of it too.
The farm we bought was not the Pyles farm
you remember, that is East of the station.
The Widow still owns 40 acres of that & wont sell.
the other 40 acres belongs 18 acres to Edmund Lype?
Completed

Two acres to Dr. Wall, and 20 acres to our
new coal men who bought Keyes House.
It has rained here most all the week.
Today some, and a raw chilly air besides,
But I have been out part of the time when it did
not rain too much locating the new
Coal Rail Road.
Illinois Legislature adjourned Thursday
morning in a fine quarrel.
I did think I would go home next week
Mean to yet; but dare not promise there
are many little things to attend too.
I have hardly given up going to Iowa
either.  I expect I ought to.
Your Own
Isaac
P.S It is Eleven o Clock - My Bedtime
Completed

Isaac, DuQuoin  Feb 22, 1857

 Elyria Ohio -

DuQuoin, Sabbath P.M.  Feb 22d
My Dearest     Would you have believed it? Abram Mitchell sits here and writes a letter to a lady every Sabbath. Well, he uses this kind of paper, and doubles the lines throughout; two lines to every one of these, and four full pages at that usually. The letters he replies to are just about the same sort. He has the ladies Miniature, but will not show it to me. Whereat I laugh at him, and tell him it is boyish.   I did not get any letter last night as I hoped to do. However I will not much complain. I have fared pretty well the past week; had at least three during the week, and the last one received Friday night, written last Monday, was seven excellent pages from yourself, and three from Sister Jennie.  Well the letters, the letters, are the principal comfort for a poor fellow away. Not by any means that I am uncomfortable here; but that I should be more comfortable at home.  I do want to see you all very much - especially My Ettie, and my baby boy.  I have never seen him walk.
Completed

This forenoon I have been at meting: I went up at 10 oclock to Sabbath School: There were very few there, as the mud is so very bad few could get there, none from out of the Village. The Preaching at 11 oclock was by Dr Fondy, the horse & watch trader (I believe I wrote you about him). He & the Big Gun of the Campbellites - if however they do not turn him off for getting found out in his horse & watch jockeying - He preaches rather better than when I heard him before, but - Oh dear - it was only words, words, words. I am heartily tired of such preaching. This afternoon is a Methodist Class Meeting, but I did not conclude to attend it. This evening Peter Hagler is to preach, and I shall attend I think; if it is muddy & dark. I do very much wish that Mr Post could preach here all the time and live here - stay here all the time himself. I know his influence would be worth so much to the place. It would affect its whole future. I have offered to give one hundred dollars per year towards his salary, if he could be here all the time ~ One hundred dollars a year till the people here are able to support him which would not be long I think. I think it would be done if the Carbondale interest did not keep him there. As it is, it is probably of no use to think of it - his being here all the time.
Completed

I do not intend to stay here many days more. Mr Keyes did not get home yesterday, but he doubtless will tomorrow. I shall fix up here as soon as possible and get away in a dew days. I want badly enough to go right home, but perhaps I shall conclude to go up to DuBuque first. At any rate I shall come home pretty soon as I can. And it will not be best to write any more to me here, after you get this letter; for I will not be here to get the letters if they come here.   Eve. I have just been to Meeting, through the much mud underfoot, and the beautiful evening in every other aspect.  It is magnificent; most brilliant star light the Evening Star rides high and really casts a shadow; and the Evening air is mild and balmy as June. It is a regular June evening for New England. There has been no frost here for most two weeks now.   Peter Hagler preached in his hard way. The man is certainly to be much respected for the excellence of his character, the amount of his influence, and the good he has done in this country. This part of Illinois certainly owes much to Peter Hagler. The high character of Perry County compared with the Counties about is in great degree due to the influence of this one ignorant, simple minded, unpretending man
Completed

But for all that is rather hard sitting to hear him preach sometimes. At the close of services he gave notice that he would hereafter preach here not only the evening but all day or any part of it not otherwise occupied every second Sabbath of the month; and also that the Baptists proposed as soon as Spring opened to build themselves a church here. Four churches here is a unclear will be pretty well for one year. But possibly they will not all get builded this summer. The audience out tonight was quite respectable in spite of the mud. I guess it always is when Peter Hagler preaches. Very few females out though. Oh I did want to be at home so today. I do want to see you all. Good night Ettie, My Ettie, kiss P.W. for me. If I were there now I should wake him up kissing him; and perhaps hiss his Mother somewhat also. Goodnight & all good blessings to you. Isaac
Completed

Isaac Duquoin Feb 23. 1857

 Elyria Ohio

Du Quoin
Monday Evening Feb 23 1857
Ettie My Ettie   Tonight came your letter of 18th inst. Every letter from home is a treat; and the longer I am away from home , not only the more I want to go home, but the more I both long for and enjoy the letters from home.  It seems my letters are nearly twice as long lately in getting from here to Elyria, as yours in coming from there here. I am glad you have warm weather there. Here it has been very warm for nearly two weeks. This morning there was the least tinge of hoar frost upon boards none showed upon the ground. And it was the coldest morning I think since Feb 11th. Most of last week was cloudy & rainy. Yesterday and today as clear and bright as could be and air is mild and soft as June or the latter end of May in New England.  Your first visit to the West Falls! I did not think that you had never been there before.  If the rains continue at Elyria you will be likely to have cistern water enough to last awhile. Do you
Completed

you at all try letting it onto the water pipes from the upper tank? Cannot very well I suppose on account of the non connection at the store. You could though by shutting the cocks in the connection pipe in the kitchen so as not to let the water into the cylinder at all.  You let in the water by turning a stop cock under the East end of the upstairs Tank, you know, first closing the two stop socks at the head of the waste pipes in the back cellar. I will fix it alright when I get there.   Mr Keyes arrived from St Louis tonight  Reports the Ohio & Mississippi R.R. from St Louis to Sandoval on the ILL. Central to be in a frightful condition; Whole track, ties, rail, and all entirely out of sight in the Mud in many places. The Train he went in on Thursday last was twenty four hours from Sandoval to St Louis, some 60 miles; and then no through train from that one till today.  Passengers through only by walking from one train to another across the worst places.  This Road is worse than ever before. It is about the worst time ever was. Last Winter was as severe frost perhaps, but it went out very gradually, and the R.R. Tracks did not
Completed

not feel it much. But now it has gone out with abundant rains; the ground is so soft as to be hardly passable for teams or horses anywhere, and the R.R. Tracks are in danger of sinking in it altogether.   In the letter I mailed this morning I told you I had got about through here. I do not mean to remain more than a day or two longer.  But I think I shall go to DuBuque, that is, if I find the Rail Road in that direction is like to be in any decent condition.   I expect I might not go home without going there.   I will of course keep writing to you almost every day as usual. Perhaps when I come back I may come down here on my way home. If there is any thing I want to hear telegraph to me next Monday or Tuesday say at Julien House DuBuque.  Just a few words to let me know you are all well you might send to Telegraph Office and do me good considerable, and cost little.   10 words or less beside the direction, and signature is a message. Anything over ten words costs a little more.   Telegraph Office in Griswold's Book Store.   Your Own  Isaac.
Completed

27 Feb. 57

 DuBuque

Julien House DuBuque Iowa
Friday Night Feb. 27. 1857
My Dear Wife   I wish I was at home tonight. I do. Still I am very comfortable here. This is a first rate house comfortable in every respect; but it is not home. I wrote you from Galena this morning while waiting for the Train, which due at 7 or a little after did not get along till near noon. However when it did come, it brought us up to Dunleith very carefully & safely, and I immediately crossed over the river here to Dubuque, and took up my quarters at this house, a fine one, named like the city after the old, half French, half Spanish, half Indian Miner who was so distinguished here among the Indians & Borderers years ago.  Julien DuBuque, half savage as he was, a "bold, bad man", small in stature, but strong in intellect & passion, held great sway in this region for many long years; and impressed his influence for years more
Completed

Mining & Gambling, you know have very much gone together every where; and here has been years past one of the worst places in the country in every such respect. But Eastern Emigration, Churches & Schools have done a great work here; and now I suppose DuBuque & Galena are about as respectable places in all respects as Western Town average. R.B. Mason is expected here probably next Monday. I cannot tell how long I shall remain here, some days next week I expect. Do you remember Kingsbury  W.H. Kingsbury? He was Bailey Broad & Co.'s Bookkeeper Agent &c. in their I&C Div. Track laying. He used to be at DuQuoin some before you left there. He is now Col. Mason's agent and Bookkeeper here. I expected I had a cousin or two here; but I do not find the name here in the Directories. So perhaps they have died or moved away.   I called tonight upon Rev. John C. Holbrook, the Pioneer of Congregationalism here in the North West; Pastor of the Cong. Church here. Pioneer as he is he is quite a young man
Completed

I called upon him to get or find if I could get the Congregational Book of Plans for Church building; which I wanted to help DuQuoin's people get up a plan for their church.  Mr. Holbrook told me there was probably but one book of the kind here, his, but he would let me have that, and he would send for another. As he said he could do without inconvenience, I thanked him especially, and took the book. I liked the Mr Holbrook in his study, and Sabbath night will probably write to you how I like him in his pulpit.   Rail Roads appear to be quite the subject of conversation here now. And a great project is on foot now for a bridge across the Mississippi River here. It will probably be built in spite of the quarrelling of St Louis and the whole Steam Boat interest against the Rock Island Bridge, and every other project of the kind.  It is acknowledged now that Rail Roads & Railway interests
Completed

have rights, even when there interests may conflict with other & older rights. A few years since it was not allowed that any amount of interest or necessity could authorize any sort of inconvenience to the interests concerned in keeping Navigable rivers open.   Well I must study my Book of Plans awhile tonight to know which I had better recommend to our DuQuoin people.  I wish I knew just how well and comfortable you are tonight. Well I hope to get home in a week.  Maybe not.   All good be with you!  Your own   Isaac
Completed

4 March 57  DuBuque

Julien House  DuBuque Ia.   Wednesday Noon  March 4th

My Dearest

 Well I do not suppose that  Jas. Buchanan is yet President of the United States of America. Neither am I Chief Engineer of the great DuBuque, St Peters & St Paul Rail Road. But both may be before night. I will will not now institute a comparison of probabilities upon the two questions.   R.B. Mason arrived last night in the Night I found him at 9 A.M. today busy enough. He told me at once of his meeting with newly organized --~ well I cannot tell the name of the R.R. Co.  But it is one of the Line which receive of the great Iowa Land Grant: the line is from Lyons - miles south of DuBuque across the whole state of Iowa. Mr Mason said he mentioned my name to them, and if I liked that project, would give me letters & try what could be done there.  But thought I would like DuBuque better; And at once gave me a letter  about the best one I ever read, ex-
Completed

except perhaps one he gave me two years ago to the Directors of ILL. Central R.R. But I am making a long story. - this letter was to F.A. Bissell Esq., President of the DuBuque, St. Peters & St. Paul R.R.'s who are anxious to have their line surveyed and located as soon as possible. L.D.V. Mason, a cousin of R.B. Mason commenced a Survey for them last fall, and this Spring none of them can find him. Mr Bissell, whom I found in the U.S. Court and who is a leading lawyer as well as Capitalist here; was much pleased with Mr R.B. Mason's letter; concluded I was just what they wanted, introduced me to sundry of their Directors, and proposes to call a meeting this afternoon to see what they will decide to do. The pressing thing with them is to get a new route through the Bluffs out of the City. The DuBuque & Pacific Line runs down the Miss. River two or three miles to the Mouth of the Catfish Creek to go out on. This the DuBuque people do not like, as it looks towards a Bridge across the River below DuBuque which would benefit Galena at DuBuque expense. The City of DuBuque has subscribed 1/4 Million to the D. St. P. & St. P. R.R. and will
Completed

will had 1/2 Million more making 3/4 Million if they can get a new line directly out of the City.   But I am cruel writing this long rigmarole of statement in which you do not fell interested at all, instead of what you do want to know. -  Whether I am coming home, how soon, and how long I will stay.  Well, I cannot tell - Probably if I do make arrangement with the D.S.P. & S. P. they will want me to commence as soon as possible. I should go right home in a few days but stay only a week or two.  What do you think of that.   Oh Dear - come to think of it - what shall we do.  I almost do not want to to to Rail Roading any more - I will not be away from you all the time, or very long.  I will not take any place, if I cannot get things to suit pretty well.  I presume though we can find some place to suit us in this great North West perhaps better than at Elyria.   If Mother comes out this Spring we will want to stay in Elyria, and I will be there whenever I can. If she does not I should if I do get into this, try to make arrangements to get you out here before
Completed

before the heat of the Summer. But it is to soon to make arrangements now.   I shall be home first.   I hoped a Telegram from you yesterday - but did not get it.   Your own  Isaac

I must quit or lose my dinner
Completed

2d March 57  DuBuque
Julien House  DuBuque Iowa
Monday Evening  March 2 '57
My Dearest   Well, I have had quite a trip today. I started quite early, too  early to get any breakfast except a bit of dry bread. I walked two miles down to "the hollow", where the DuBuque and Pacific R.R. leaves the river, and where its temporary buildings are, before the expensive Depot grounds in the slough can be finished. The iron Train "Reconstruction, was to go out about Seven oclock; but the Engine got off the Rails on the hard curve of the Iron track, and they did not get started till Eleven.  But I improved the time by climbing the Bluff to "DuBuque's Grave" the grave of old Julien DuBuque of whom I wrote you a few days since. I certainly could not but admire the old fellow's taste if his selection of a burial place. It is a high narrow Bluff, perpendicular or overhanging at the end, projecting into the river between Cat fish Creek & 'the Hollow', which Hollow was the great smelting place for the Lead ore mined in the Bluff cities around. This DuBuque's Bluff overlooks completely DuBuque & Dunleith, some three miles up the river and the whole mighty Mississippi flowing between its magnificent bluff banks a mile or two apart, for many miles North & South.   The Tomb was a sort of Artificial Case, excavated on the point of the bluff, and built up of rough masonry which still remains. It had a great cover
on side:  Col. M did not arrive. I shall stay a day longer. He got to Chicago Sat. but was delayed there
Completed

cap of solid lead melted into the stone work but that has all disappeared. The Cedar Cross which stood at the head of the Tomb, is most gone, and much decayed; but the stump of it that is left is pretty thoroughly covered with names - to which I was not at all tempted to add mine. I was tempted though to sit all day upon that sunny bluff, among those few old trees, to gaze upon the ancient river while hurrying on its olden course, and the newborn cities springing up along its sides.  But I crept and slid down the old bluff's steep snowy Northern side, and climbed upon the Locomotive "Sioux City", which with its load of Iron crawled slowly and windingly out among the Bluffs and up the crooked little valley of the Catfish Creek, until I finally emerged into or upon the high broad Prairies of Iowa. In twenty Miles the Rail Road rises 550 feet or more. The Track is very rough, laid on a half finingled Road bed, on frost & ice & snow, in a very cold Winter. So our Iron Train did not get out to the track layers till 3 P.M. and as soon as it could unload started back again. I arrived at the Julien House at 8 P.M. hungry enough, I assure you, for I did not get much dinner. But I enjoyed the trip much. If Col. R.B. should reach DuBuque tonight I shall probably leave it tomorrow night   Well its time to go to bed   Good Night   Isaac
Completed

Above? for a while, these qualities seem to Change then again above the mouth of a beautiful brook, on Wisconsin side among pretty hills, it becomes as before
These grassy sloping bluffs with the occasional terraced wall, are beautiful exceedingly.  Oh if I only had another pair of eyes to look with
Some of the way there these terraced walls look as if they must have been built up by the hand of man. Enormous Protection walls, built up by the giants of long gone ages against this Father of Waters. As if he used once to rise in his pride 100 ft. or so upon their sides. How their battlements frown upon us , Now they rise like Castles over our heads, there must be the mighty residences of those giants.

And again beautiful sloping grassy hills perhaps crowned with turretts of rock. Hills of every shape & form & position; as they permit the brooks which wind among them to find their way to the Father of Waters.
How the grass grows among the Trees, & the rocks peep up among the grass. -------- Here after Miles following The Wisconsin Bluffs we shoot across among the islands some covered with Trees, and some low with grass; hundreds of channels among the Islands. miles away towards Iowa Bluffs. Oh the Exceeding beauty of these quiet green Islands! and the bold bluffs in the distance. Why the Hudson is no more to be compared with this than Mole holls with Mountains.
Are these beautiful banks & bluffs, now untrodden by man sometime to be built up with Palaces, like the Hudson; Why not? Their dwellers must live in "Joy forever" of the sight of beauty makes it.

Massasoit House, Springfield
                                                                                                       Tuesday P.M. Sept. 21
   My Dearest                                                                                                     1858    
        Must drop you a line tonight that you may know of our progress. First very warm weather: Perhaps though you have already noticed that item. Staid at Cleveland till 3.50 P.M. Anna Moody's Cousin or Uncle, a good natured & apparently well to do Irishman, named Quinn, was at the Depot waiting for her, & very heartily carried her & Hattie up Town to his house; so I saw no more of them till 3.45 I dined heartily & viewed the City, as the weather would. 3.50 P.M. Cars, & no stop over 15 miles. till we reached here at 2 oclock this P.M. Hattie in pretty good spirits throughout; but did not sleep much. Anna M. did heartily, though a good deal sick when awake. Hattie was sick some this Morning when travelling rather fast; Pretty thoroughly tired out & used up when we reached here. So I got her a good room at the Massasoit, & she will be finely rested before tomorrow morning I presume.

I may go to Boston tomorrow night; but doubtful will keep you advised occasionally.

 I feel first rate myself. Travelling agrees with me you know
Completed

I should like much to know just how you & the little ones get on.
Love & kisses

          Isaac

Isaac Sept. 24/58                                                        Augusta Maine Friday Sept. 24
Elyria  
Dear Nettie

                  Well I have not got to Bangor yet. I wrote you from Springfield - Tuesday I think it was

Wednesday, went up to South Hadley. I remained there from 9 to 10 A.M. till 5? P.M. Left Hattie in much better spirits than I expected. I think she liked at first better than she expected. She was much pleased with Miss Tolman the receiving Teacher, Miss Jessup was not about. Miss Chapin sick. Miss Tolman told me she had relatives named De Witt.  She should think of her on that account, and would take good care of her; seemed specially interested in her. She gave her to a Miss Reeder of Binghampton N.Y. as a Room Mate, whom she described as "a most lovely girl; one of our best scholars". One of the most desirable rooms in the house, second story, same floor as recitation rooms, front room etc. Hattie was very much pleased with Miss Reeder, could not help loving her at once she said. Miss Tolman assigns Rooms & room Mates for first four weeks, then those who desire can change.
Hattie will like South Hadley I am pretty confident
Completed

I left Holyoke at 5 P.M. Wednesday 
Reached Springfield at 8 a.m.
Left           "              at 10 ""
Reached Boston        " 1 A.M.
Slept four or five hours -- and yesterday came down here. Maine State Fair being in operation concluded to stop over for 24 hours. Great Equestrian Performance of Ladies yesterday P.M. Great attraction to very great crowds
Great ridiculous mess?
Fine cattle show
a exhibition of products, manufactured articles etc. in the rooms of the State House.
Last Evening Speech from Jefferson Davis the distinguished Southern fireater.

Isaac Toledo Ohio                                                              Island House Toledo, Ohio
Feb. 1 1859                                                                                Tuesday Eve. February 1st 1859
Dearest Nettie

  I have to wait here this evening, and believe I can do no better than to write a bit to you. It seems already a long time since I left you & the little ones. I called at Dr. Dascombs'. They are all well, and said they wanted to see you. The Doctor went over to the Cars with me, and introduced me to a young Mr. Cowles, a son of Prof. Cowles of Oberlin, a Theological Student, a tall fine looking young fellow, going out to Bellevue where he is preaching this winter. He was very good company. On the cars also was Rev. Jos. Eells of Cleveland, going out to Fremont to preach this evening - unusual religious interest there at present. Had considerable conversation with him about Elyria etc.
The Toledo Wabash & Western Train does not leave here until about 1 oclock, so I have quite a waiting before me.

I guess Rolling will take care of things pretty well if not reprove him. I have instructed him about the Furnace etc. If there should come extreme cold weather so as to require unusual fires, you might look down cellar occasionally and about the pipes etc. to see that all is right. If any thing goes wrong any where in any thing that Rollin can not fix satisfactorily call upon Mr. Waldo or the Doctor, or
Completed

or Mr. Crane about the furnace.
The $5.00 I left on the bureau for Mr. Darling I gave to him myself.
If you want Crushed Sugar send Rollin to get a bucket full - He need say nothing about to 100 lbs. You can call & pay for it yourself if you want to - or not -
I want to know how you get along tonight. Please write very often.
This Pen is so extra mean I can hardly write, but I am too lazy to unpack my Valise to get my own.

                                                          Truly
                                                                   Isaac
Completed

Isaac Springfield Ill.
Feb. 3d 1859                                                                     Springfield Ill. Feb. 3d 1859
My Dearest

  I wrote you from Toledo a bit of a note the evening after I left home.

That evening I spent till 10 P.M. in the very well appointed Reading Room of the Young Men's Association of Toledo. Then in the Island House Reading Room till about 1 oclock A.M. when I left on the Western bound Train. Arrived at the Illinois State Line at 1 P.M. and here at 7-15 P.M. Went with Mitchell to his hired house. Mitchell's wife and his wife's Mother who is with her this Winter, seemed quite interested to hear from you, and promised to call upon you. They know all about Dunbarton people; The Mrs., (both Mrs. Stinson's), Capt. & Wm. Stinson wifes are Cousins. Her name was Bessy Parker, You probably remember her & her sister Abby Parker; she said her brother Louis used to go to School  to you there at Parker's I suppose.
They live very snugly, renting a small house not far from the Depot & R.R.d Offices. The Ladies do not like Springfield as well as Urbanna, where you know that
Completed

Mitchell has built a pretty good house, and lived pretty comfortably.
I rather think Mitchell will stay here,
It is uncertain however, about that
This forenoon I have been up to the State House, and found there John Condit Smith as natural as ever, and still larger; he is really growing corpulent, his cheeks stick out considerable - really quite fat; it rather improves his appearance I think.
Says he shall take occasion to call at Elyria. He is a man of magnificent schemes truly. His magnificent Land Schemes of two years since have left him very much in the lurch, as indeed have many others in the same time. As he says he has been pretty well 'busted up', but he has still great things ahead; certain Swamp Land plans which he has in tow, he has been at Washington, and is now clearly following the Illinois Legislature; one of the most active Lobby Members - and expects his commission will ammount to the trifling sum of Sixty Thousand dollars $60,000.00) Perhaps!
I shall stay here all day to day.
Tonight 9.15 P.M. go over to Decatur - sleep there, and the tomorrow Friday go down to DuQuoin.
Completed

How long I shall want to stay at DuQuoin of course I know no more than I did when I left home. One thing I shall intend to get home as soon as I fairly can. Though doubtless I ought in regard to my own interest to stay but here and look after my matters here more than I have of late.
I have most to large a stake in Illinois to leave the State entirely for two years at a time.
My Pecuniary interest would have dictated that I should reside at DuQuoin.

Well I shall hope to hear from you, when, or soon after I reach DuQuoin.
                                             Love & Kisses
                                                       Your
                                                            Isaac
Completed

Isaac  DuQuoin Ill.
Feb. 13 1859

                                                                                  Du Quoin, Perry Co. Illinois
                                                                                  Sabbath P.M. Feb. 13th 1859

My Dearest

            Excuse this kind of paper: it is what is left in my room from the remains of the past week's work, and I do not care to go over to the Office for more. To avoid the interruptions and noise of the office I have the past week withdrawn books, papers, bills & plans from the office to this my quiet Chamber in Mr. Keyes' house, and here I have worked every day  & evening. Mr. Keyes some of the times with me and sometimes otherwise engaged.

This Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, hardly going out at all from the house. Saturday I took Mr. Keyes' horse & buggy and went down to the Old Town. The Old place  - our first home - looks rather hard. The Store part you know moved away, and all left in dreadfully un-fixed condition. The Man Turner, to whom Mr. Keyes sold it, has never any thing but mischief there, has never paid any thing for it or towards it, and now it has finally come back into Mr. Keyes' hands again. I hope he will fix it up or sell it to some one who will. It is too bad. It is really the handsomest grounds, yard, & shrubbery tree is in all Southern Illinois. There is so many and so various evergreens are splendid. Keyes would give $25.00 apeice for them now at the new place. I do not know but a hundred. From there or from the Seminary the new City of DuQuoin shows admirably. It is spread over a good
Completed

deal of ground, & looks finely from a distance. The little grove at the lower end of the 'Park' has all been cut down.
Geo. Milford Hinkley, you know, has now his store right opposite his house, is quite a thriving man, has made money much of late years. I stopped at his house to dinner. Mrs. H. as much given to Cooking as ever, and getting fat as a Pig.  Burgess lives in a little new house past East of Hinckley's store. I did not see Mrs. Burgess. She was gone away somewhere when I called.
Hiram Hinckley has sold his house & sundry acres of land with it to the Seminary - new house you know, or built I think since you were there - in front of the old log house; and he has built a new larger & better house, very good & convenient, though not quite yet finished - down the road - 1/2 mile nearly near the Middle of his farm. All the folks glad to see me and delighted to hear from Mrs. Metcalf who you know is especially idolized by the people of the vicinity, however they may think of her husband. There never was any body there they loved quite as much, and remember so much. Fanny Hinckley still stutters - almost painfully - when excited. She is a sweet girl though and the little Margaret, whom you remember is most as big  as any body. On the road I saw Anne McCluer and at the Seminary Ellen Wall & Sarah Richie and their eyes all sparkled to hear from you.
I went all over the Seminary building with Milford H. It is really a quite a fine building; but under the management of Miss Paine & Mr. Wood it has cost much more than it ought. I think it could make
Completed

To contrast to furnish such buildings at $12,000.00 or east I rather think at $10,000.000 and they say that has cost at least $16,000.00, and they have spent someway about twenty one or two thousand.
I saw Mrs. Saunders who is now nominally the head of the school. They will have some more suitable head in the spring doubtless. The school now has only 16 or 17 scholars! The school almost completely broken up by the conduct of Miss Paine. What a time they have had.
It appears she was 'engaged' to the worthless shiftless boy three or four years ago. It appears that their conduct caused some scandal among the children or scholars then, but the old folks thought nothing of it. He went away east to school; whether she paid his expenses I do not know. He came back and the community were thunderstruck by the Announcement that they were to be married the next day! All were invited to the wedding, but nobody went. He had positively nothing to live on; his friends all poor as cats. His wife took him right into the seminary to room with her there! And then they continued in spite of all could be done, The Board of Trustees, after all she had done or tried to do for the Institution, did not like to discharge her. She refused to resign & Mr. Wood, Weeks' uncle upheld her, and compelled the Burbanks to help him to do so. Moreover Weeks took airs & authorities upon himself, as head, or husband of the head, of the school, attended in the committee room, wanted to be Secretary etc. etc.
At last I suspect Mr. Pease, My friend the R.R. Suptdt., who had become a member of the board, had to take upon himself the natural authority of his nature, and command a peace. Mt. & Mrs. Weeks left, went to Pinckneyville, he studies law, and she writes upon the subject of her sacrifices and persecutions.
The people at the Old Town are very sore upon the subject; they think she robbed the Seminary most egregiously. Furniture & books & bedding etc. etc. which they thought had been donated to the Seminary, she claimed
Completed

as given to her, and carried off with her, and moreover now claims that the Seminary is indebted to her some $900.00
They say that though Weeks is too shiftless ever to support himself, there is no doubt that his wife will manage or maneuver a living for him somehow. Perhaps you remember my telling you of her buying some furniture of Mr. Keyes for the Seminary. She send Brad Skinner to Keyes for the bill, saying the money was ready. Keyes made out the bill about half price, and receipting it gave to Skinner to deliver & bring back the money. But in return of the Messenger Mr. Keyes was astonished, amazed & vexed at receipt of a polite note of thanks for the liberal donation of furniture! He pocketed it as best he might and said nothing. Not long since he received a note from Mrs. Weeks inquiring whether he did not intend that donation of furniture to herself rather than to the Seminary!  He coolly answered that he certainly did not intend it as a donation to the Seminary, and so Mrs. Weeks carried it off!
This forenoon, to Church. Mr. Hawkins the Methodist preached, Methodists occupy the Church half the time. Baptists who are about building a large church to seat 4 or 500, use the Campbellite Church when on alternate Sabbaths there is no meeting of the 'Disciples', and the rest of the time in a school house. 

  Property affairs here prosperous. Keyes has sent me about half the money he has collected: but owes me some $2,000.00 or more paid to him in labor, materials etc. on Mill, houses etc.
 Bills Receivable say $18,000.00 dollars all drawing 10 per cent interest, all safe. Nearly 200 lots unsold worth from $50. to $100.00 each, perhaps average 100.00 each.
 When there is a Reservation Block 53 belonging solely entirely to Metcalf would bring I presume $2000,00 today at the least. Then the 18 acres joining Town which Metcalf reserved for his heirs, on which the Nurserymen agrees to keep fenced & taxes paid & pay 50. per year. Then the 40 acres a mile off, where I ought to have built & lived now. Then the Coal Interest, I guess we shall do Nettie. This is from Isaac.
Completed

Milo 
         Aug. 25 1859
                                                                                              Milo, Piscataquis Co. Maine
                                                                                                      Thursday Aug. 25th 1859

My Dearest

              I am afraid you may think I have not been very good about writing letters since I left home. I wrote once from Lewiston N.Y. and most especially intended to write again from Montreal, but failed. I did write from Bangor on Sunday to go by first mail after we arrived there. Monday I with great joy received letter from you, the first you wrote, and yesterday morning, just as I was getting into the Stage to come up here, another, written the Friday before; and enclosing the ones from Mr. Keyes. So I feel tolerably easy about you, knowing that you began to get along tolerably comfortably. Another thing relieved me a good deal, to hear of the Tank filling up, & not leaking.

I have been quite anxious about that. If it had leaked badly, it would have been quite a trouble to you, especially if coming in the night.
I write to you Sabbath day.
Monday & Tuesday, staid at Bangor partly
Completed

with Eliab, in his Counting Room, and about his business, and looking at the ressults, and partly with the Children. Some one had to stay pretty close by them all the time. Irving is so quick, and nervous; & michiefous, that come to get Wilder with them they needed that constant watching. Here they appear to do very much better together.
Tuesday, I wrote & Mailed a long letter ( 7 or 8 Pages of Note size) to Dunbarton, telling of our Journey, and making enquiries about the Wedding etc. So as to know when I shall decide to go there.
We came up here yesterday, Wednesday, by stage - terribly dusty - It is a very dry time here, about the most so I ever saw. Found Charles cutting grain, and went to work helping get in some of it. So I pitched on three loads of oats before dark. And before Morning it began to rain, a very nice gentle rain to do a great deal of good.
Hattie De Witt is up to Brownville Mother here.
Mother & Anna & Albina have got to work already this Morning fitting up Charlie etc. And Anna is talking some of taking Mary with her.
Completed

The Children here are all about as of old. The baby "George" 7 mos. old is a great fat stout boy sitting on the floor at play.
The little one at Bangor "Edith Ely" is the most physically of any of their Children, Weight 14 lbs at 3 mos three lbs more than our baby, and the extreme of good nature etc. showing still stronger by contract with the other nervous slender little ones.

 It is perhaps hardly decided yet whether Hattie will go home with us or not.
Well, I believe I shall have to stop as Charles is just going down to P.O.
You must call upon Mr. Waldo for every thing that is needed - and write me particularly.
Kiss the Babies for me.

And receive for yourself all manner of love

                                                  Your Own
                                                           Isaac S.
Completed

Isaac Milo
Aug 28 '59

                                                                                              Milo, Maine, Aug. 28th 1859
                                                                                              Sabbath Afternoon

My Dear One

  Let me see; We came up here by Stage, on Wednesday, Thursday I wrote a letter to you, but did not quite get it to the Post Office in Season. So that I suppose it did not go to Bangor until Saturday, as there is now a Mail but Three times a Week. And you will think have been rather negligent about writing. I expect there is a letter for me at Bangor from you, and perhaps another from Dunbarton. Thursday it rained all day. a great rain Storm, the first for a long while; it had been a very dry time. 

Friday, Anna & I went up to Brownville with Charles' horse & Chaise stopping a while by the way under Brownville Bridge, in violent Shower. James, Lissy, Hattie, Mills Ryder & Franks Searles, a cousin of James, visiting there from Sutton Mass. had gone on an Excursion to Katahdin Iron Works where they had a fine time, climbing the Iron Mountain, sailing the Lake, and getting slightly wet by the shower. Wilder and myself came down here, by eight o clock. Wilder sleeping most of the way. Wilder is a very good boy, very little trouble in any way - was some, at least needed watching some at Bangor with Irving; but here or at Brownville none at all hardly, except that he must talk rather too much. His health is first rate, like mine, eats any thing, and every thing, and a great deal of it; Nothing hurts him in any way, and he grows fat. The change of climate suits him. Anna & Hattie will come down here, probably tomorrow, And Almeda too tomorrow, or the next day, to see Mother etc.
Completed

We shall go to Bangor, perhaps all together with Charles' horses & big carriage, perhaps by stage on Thursday or Friday.
Wilder & I shall probably go to Dunbarton on Friday or Saturday. (Arrangements not fully made, for I have not yet heard from Dunbarton.) But probably I & Wilder shall go first to Dunbarton; stay over Sabbath.
Mother & Anna go to Boston on Monday, stay in Boston perhaps a day or two, and, I meet them there perhaps on Wednesday of next week, and go on west.
These Arrangements however, are as yet only problematical.
But I think we will get home by the end of next week.
I suppose there are Water and Musk Melons both in the Garden, which ought to be eaten. Do you find them, or dare to eat them? The thing I intended to mention to Mr. Waldo, but forgot, and it is now too late. I had some Early peas of which I planted the ripened seed the first of July, and they were nearly ripe the second time when I came away. I intended to ask Mr. Waldo to plant a few of them, as soon as ripe enough, and try to raise the third crop.
But you should have green peas to eat nowadays. And you may enjoy them all the better, as you can rely upon them as containing, not any even incipient bugs.
I am almost homesick today for lack of a letter from you.
I got one last night for Anna, but she will not be here to read it until tomorrow.
I will get a letter or two by tomorrows mail I think.

 They talk some of having little Mary go back with us to live with Anna, go to school and so forth. What do you think of it?
 I should like to know whether you have been to Church today, and how tired you are; and how the children behave. and a good many other things about you. And I should like to kiss my Ettie.
                                                                                Sincerely
                                                                                    Isaac.
Completed

Elyria  July 18 1860

 Elyria  July 18 '60  Wednesday Evening  Day of the Eclipse

Dearest   I have just written to George, two or three pages, as you requested.  I would give considerable to know just how you are at this present time. 9.30 P.M. Fairly started on your long tiresome night ride from Buffalo to Albany. Yes I suppose you must have left Buffalo before Six oclock.  I am afraid you are very tired, and your head aches before this time
on side: 
quite a mess of blackberries for supper
Completed

Even more than it has all day; and that you will not get much chance to rest tonight.  I shall be quite anxious till I can hear from you.  I shall wonder if you get home tomorrow; Thursday Evening. If you go right on without detention, you would get to Worcester by Noon probably; and could get round to Manchester or Concord early in the afternoon. I am afraid you will get home sick.  Do be careful of yourself  Take your time to rest & recruit yourself  Visiting alone, is the very time to do that.
Completed

I found rather a lonesome house here when I got home from the Depot. However the children have all been very good, and all appear very well.  Charles says "I do not want my Mama not to come home". Wilder says "I wanted to go with my Mama."   We had a very fine Shower here this afternoon; and both the boys were very anxious for fear you would get wet.  I hope the shower was extensive enough to lay the dust where you ride tonight and tomorrow.  You must not worry about the children, or any thing else, so as
Completed

enjoy your visit nicely  All will go on just as well as need be.  The children do, and will do first rate.  Sarah is good as you could ask; Even Zillah seems to feel her weight of responsibility, and to try specially to be careful in all things.  Enjoy your visit & not hurry home, on our account. I do not know as you can read this. I did not know the pen was so bad till I look back upon it.  Of course you will write as soon as you get home, or before if you stop.  And write very frequently.   Your own  Isaac
Completed

Elyria  July 22 1860                 Elyria

                                              Sabbath Eve  July 22 1860

Dearest Nettie    I considerably expected a letter from you last night, but it did not come. From this I judge that you did not stop at Westboro, & not writing till you got home, even if you got home Thursday night, We would not get a letter before Monday night.   You want to know for the first thing how we all are here.

Generally:  Very well.
 Particularly: Baby, about as usual; Her bowls were a little out of order when you left, and a day or two before; and have been slightly so since; but are better today, better I think than for a week or two. She is very good, amuses herself on the floor and with playthings &c. by the hour. She is very little trouble nights, sleeps in the bed altogether - has not dirtied
Completed

a diaper in the night since you went away. She takes to her father greatly since your absence: makes for me with shouting whenever I come in her sight.   Charlie & Wilder are evidently better than they have been: seem to be getting entirely over their cough; and have great appetites; better than any time since they began to cough.  I have been afraid they would hurt themselves with fruit; but I try to have them eat only the ripe, and that does them good. Some of the early apples are getting quite ripe now you know.   The rest of us are well as usual.   Mother. I was a little afraid would try to do too much, and tire herself out, but she seems to do finely.   The girls do very well, better than you would expect. Sarah takes fair care of the baby, and seems very reliable about it.
Completed

I incline to think Sarah is rather unusually careful, reliable, and trustworthy for a girl of her age. She is certainly smart & capable.  Zillah does  better than usual. I imagine she takes extra pains to be careful about every thing.  Mother looks after her some, and everything seems to go on very well.   Charles is entirely devoted to the New Barn, which progressed some.  Anna, wonderful to relate, was up here Friday to spend the day! She came in the forenoon, staid to dinner & all afternoon, and the Dr came up to tea; and then they were detained by a shower till about dark. And I guess the children down there all lived through it.   Thursday morning I went over to Oberlin; to see that Miss Helen Martin of Mrs Dascombs' about our
Completed

our schools; but found she had engaged to stay in the Oberlin Public School. I carred over Mrs Calkins & Matilda Waldo, who is to stay there till after Commencement; and Mr Waldo worked for me meanwhile.   My cough continues, but perhaps is hardly as bad as before you left. It makes a good excuse for me not to go to Church this evening though.  Mother & Charles have gone. It has been a rainy day; rained all the morning till after Meeting time, and several showers since. It has rained every day since you went away more or less, beginning with a short shower at  2 P.M. Wednesday: a heavy shower Wednesday night Moderate one Thursday P.M. another Friday, a heavy one yesterday P.M. and rained more or less every night.   Meeting was very thin this morning. Mr Wilbur preached
Completed

an excellent sermon from "Behold the Lamb of God which taketh away the Sin of the World".  It was not Christ as a Teacher; it was not the innocence of Christ; but Christ as a Lamb - that is as a sacrifice for Sin, which takes away sin.  Went to Town Plank S.S. this P.M. as usual, and found school nearly as large as usual.   There was a boy drowned near here last night, just by Mr Snow's about Sun set, Willie Laundon a Ridgeville, Sugar Ridge Boy, Nephew of Mr Thomas Laundon, and living there to do chores & go to school.  About 14 years old.   The Body was not recovered for an hour or more. Charles & I went down & both went in to try to find him, but did not succeed. There happened to be no boat anywhere near, and nothing to be done except by swimming & diving till
Completed

it was too late.  I believe though it as half an hour at least, after boats did get there, and Charles & I left before the body was recovered. My breath was so short, that I could not stay under water long enough to amount to anything hardly.  Mother though[t] Charles & I would both catch cold &c. but I guess we did not; I rather strained my short breath, but have got about over it I guess.   There came, the day after you left a letter from Susie Brigham which I will save till you get back  I guess there is nothing special in it for which to send it to you.   I wrote to George & Mailed Thursday Morning, and also a letter to you which I presume you have got ere this.   I am quite anxious to hear from you. I expect you got very tired indeed before you got to New H.
Completed

Perhaps were made sick almost or quite. I am anxious to hear. Take time, and rest yourself; and be careful of yourself. And do write often, & particularly.  Do not think you must hurry back. Take time to make your visit, and recruit yourself by absence from the toilsome cares of your family.  Write frequently, and we shall get along. And, by straining? a point or two, you can get along yourself, if you hear from us regularly.  If you should go down to Bangor, I wish you would, if you can continue to bring it, have Eliab give you some of that  coarse duck*, you know what for Their pants. You know we cannot get it here. I can get Nothing to suit me as well.   Well - Write - of course -  Good Night & God's Blessing  Sincerely  Isaac

 duck is a heavy cotton cloth
Completed

Elyria  July 27 1860

 Elyria  July 27 1860

Nettie Dearest   Your good letter of the 21st-23d came tonight. The other one mailed the 21st came on Wednesday, having been urgently expected, for two or three days.   I wrote to you on Wednesday Night after you started, the receipt of which you acknowledged, and again on Sabbath night which you had not received at that time, but perhaps have ere this.  There is little new to write you tonight. We all get along nicely and about after our usual sort.  Charles & I are quite busy about the Barn. Two half days this week we have been up to the Woods, when Darling has been hauling Saw logs. Other days I have been part of the time at
Completed

Brook's Planing Mill, where I have been getting lumber prepared for the barn. Yesterday I helped Mr Waldo get in some hay from over the River, and today he has been working on the barn. We stacked his hay by the side of my old barn, so that he can keep his old horse in my old barn this Winter, if I do not move it.   Wednesday the Crandall girls had a PicNic Dinner at the Junction, north of Town. Crandalls, Jenkins, Wilburs, P. Bliss, DeWitts & about 20   T.L. Nelson & I.S. Metcalf especially invited "on account of their present widowed condition"  I did not train in that company excusing myself on account of pressing business.  Today carried Mother to Drs. and with Anna to call at Mrs Wilbur's. Charlie & Little May sitting in the carriage, or driving round the streets Wilbur boys Rolly De
Completed

[De]Witt mean while.  Wilbur went down to Drs to stay all night.   The Children all are very well I think now.  Baby sleeps better nights nowadays I think than she has for a long time.  Last Night waked me only once and night before only  twice.   Wilder & Charlie may be considered very good little boys.   What shall we do with fruit? Zillah & Charlie picked nearly a half bushel of splendin great nice gooseberries. I talked of making them into Wine, but they did get into a big pudding dish of Jelly & more too.  Blackberries - words fail to express. Charlie picks a few quarts per day of Wild ones in the Grove, which we eat in pies & puddings, but the Lawtons*: well their name is legion, all fair & smooth, and about an inch in diameter the smallest way, if there be any smallest way to them.

 Lawton blackberries
Completed

I suppose they would be worth two shillings a quart in Eastern Cities.   Hope your Father & Mother are better ere this.   What shall you do for your own health? Avoid tiring yourself. Do not sit down in the house & sew all the time; be out of doors much. Keep warm. Be careful of your Bowels.  You will feel better in a few days I guess, when you get fully over your fatigue of Journeys.   Write to me frequently.  Much love to the good folks.   Sincerely  Isaac S.
Completed

Elyria  July 29 1860

  Elyria. Ohio  July 29 1860
  Sabbath Evening

Nettie Dearest   Mother & Charles have not not got home from Meeting: I didnt go this evening. I will write a bit to you I think. I wish I could know & see just how you do feel this evening. I hope having got fairly rested from your journey you feel much better. Do not stay in the house & especially sew too much. Be out of doors. If your father is well enough, and it is good for him to be out, ride about over the hills with him. It will do you more good than any thing else. If not, be sure to walk out every day & every where, often & much; not much at a time, or to get tired, but frequently. Be careful and not get fatigued. After George gets home
Completed

he will ride with you. Keep the horse a going. It will be good for both of you. Only look out that you do not get fatigued over those rough roads. What you want is the greatest amount of out door exercise you can have without fatigue.  I suppose it is just the time you cannot get much fruit there, which is a little unfortunate. Here we abound. I believe I wrote you about the Blackberries. Apples are considerable Eight or ten trees of sweet Apples small trees, but some Apples to each are ripening. The Harvest Apples are about gone. The Astrachans for sauce & pies hold out yet. Some Pears are beginning to ripen. Peaches are hardly ready yet.   We get along finely here.  I think the three Children are in better health than they have been for Months.  Wilder & Charlie are about done coughing and
Completed

Eat like young horses or pigs. They "Eat all that is set before them" at the table; and fruit as they can get it.  Charlies usual salutation to me is "Papa, Gim napp'l."   Baby too seems very well; Bowels in good condition, eats well, sleeps well & good natured. We have frequent showers since you left.  It rained part of last night & till 10 this morning when it cleared off so pleasantly that those who went to Church did not think of umbrellas. But before 12 oclock it was raining again smartly!  By 2 P.M. it cleared off again beautifully so we went to our Down Plank S.S. and had a good school; but before we got through, it was closely  clouded again, though it has not rained much yet.
Completed

Tuesday 31st
This letter not gone yet. All doing well. Baby a little diarhea from swallowing a green blackberry whole, which she picked up on the floor. She is getting over it though; and it was not as bad as before when you went away which was occasioned by swallowing a gooseberry.   The Wilbur Boys here about all day today, having a fine time, the four & Charlie & Mary Rich & Geney Murphy.   Cassius M. Clay* is to speak here Friday Afternoon.   Write Often.   Much love to you & all    Isaac


 abolitionist
