Elyria   Aug 3 1860

 Elyria Aug 3 1860

My Dearest    Your letter of the 28th ultima came to hand last night, & was very gladly received  You speak of coming home in two weeks or so.  You have no occasion to hurry home on account of the children. We all get along finely, have so far & expect to continue to do so.  You had better stay your visit out, and get yourself well recruited. Be careful of yourself and not get over fatigued. The More you ride about the better for you if you do not get over tired.  I suspect you did one day that you wrote about
Completed

When did I write to you last? Letter Mailed Tuesday last perhaps. Since then I have been pretty busy: Seeing everybody to collect Pew Rents & c. Wednesday paid Mr Wilbur $140.00  Yesterday $40.00 and perhaps more today.   This morning it rains nicely, which is very much regretted.  Cassius M. Clay* was to speak here, according to arrangement, in Court House Square at 1 P.M. today; and a great crowd was expected.  What the result will be, with this rain, I do not know.  Monthly Church was appointed for this Afternoon, but it was decided last night to give it up, on account of the expected


 abolitionist
Completed

crowd. If the weather were good, the streets would be so filled that Ladies could not get to the Meeting. And the Men would all want to hear the Speech.   I guess not both will fail.   We got letters from Brownville last night.  They enquire urgently when you & I will be there visiting. Have not heard from Bangor since you left.  How Much Money have you got left?  How much shall I send you to come home with?  I ought to have had it for you to take with you when you started from home.   We have not got our Barn fully covered yet.
Completed

Wilder has been down to Drs. most of this week, where they say he is an excellent boy. His eyes shine & he dances finely whenever he happens to see me in there or in the Street but he sticks & he is not coming home till Saturday Night.  Charlie complains a good deal of the want of "My Wiles."  He is a very good boy.   His principal word has changed from "Napple" to "A rapple."   Please Write Often   Your Own   Isaac
Completed

Elyria   Aug 5 1860

 Elyria  Aug 5 1860
 Sabbath Evening

Dearest   I believe I must write you a little this evening.   It has been a very pleasant day indeed, quite warm and yet with a fine bracing air.  Mr Wilbur preached an excellent sermon this morning from Ps. 119.11   P.M. was the S.S. Concert at the Episcopal Church, Union Concert Address by Rev Dr Wheeler Presdt of the Methodist College at Berea. I did not attend, being obliged to go to my S.S. down the Plank you know.  This Evening I have stayed at home to see to the children  Mother has not been at all all day, this morning not feeling
Completed

hardly well enough; tired with the weeks cares, Tonight she was going & the horse stood at the gate, but Charles had gone down to the Drs. & I did not get back in time to go with her. So the Girls both went the Methodist Church, where Dr Wheeler preached, as he did in Morning.   Friday I wrote you of Cass M. Clay's being here. The Morning was extremely unpropitious, very rainy till one oclock.   It did not rain at Eleven & I went out on horse back on the Oberlin Road to meet Clay, quite a troop of us.  It began to rain again & we got nicely wet.  Clay has been speaking in open air about every day for five week, and was about broken down. So he did not do credit to himself.
Completed

When he began in Court house Square, he could hardly be heard by those next to him, he was so hoarse, but after a little his voice began to come till there was no need of going to hear him.  He could be heard all over town. At least any where about the Square.  After him Hon. H.G. Blake, M. C. for this district. (Judge Bliss' successor) spoke a little and then John C. Underwood of Virginia, who is really a fine speaker  In spite of the rainy Morning there was a great crowd.   Our New S.S. Library was on hand, or partly so, this morning for the first time.   The Ladies Society amused us some. After donating Money to the S.S. to get a new Library with you know they appointed a Committee to get the Library!  Not contend
written sideways over the other writing: 
Monday Night All Well
Completed

with that! under the lead of Mrs Hall; who I suppose wanted Artema's S.S. over the River should inherit,  Since you went away they appointed another committee to dispose of the old Library! This was a little too much.  In fact on reflection, most of them saw their ridiculousness in taking the matter away from there to whom it belonged so completely, & felt a good deal ashamed of it.  So when the matter came up in S.S. today, Mr Brooks suggested they should appoint a committee not interested in any of the Mission Schools who might want the Books, and so they quickly nominated a Com. of the Opp. Mrs Cole & Mrs Darling.    Letter from Eliab last night. Mallie Metcalf just chartered for Palermo, Sicily, with new Capt.  Capt. Snow very sick.   

P.S,  We are all well.  Baby had some diarhea last week and fretted some: but is much better. Boys & rest very well.    Aff.  Isaac
Completed

Elyria  Aug 8 1860

  Aug 8 1860   Elyria

Dearest Nettie    I got your letter the same time mine was mailed, the last I wrote to you Monday night. Very glad to hear none but good news.   We have no worse here I think. Baby still has diarhea, but seems full as well as she does for a month or two. Do not worry about my cough - all in the day time, and very rarely in the night.  I do not cough I think more than the boys do, & seem entirely well. There
Completed

are always some slight remnants of the Whoop for some time I suppose.  Blackberries:  Mother & Zillah canned some, 3 or 4 tin cans I guess; Charlie has carried down Town & sold $1.50 worth of them. Some sent to Drs & some to Mr Wilburs.   Mother is afraid you will drive around, visiting &c. make yourself tired out and your health worse than when you went away.  I tell her the riding about will be good for her, if you do not get too tired.  You must be careful of yourself.
Completed

I will enclose in this $10 for you, and if I can get it five more.    You have not written how much you had left of the money you started with   I do not even know any thing how much your fares cost you in getting there.   I would send XX today if I had it now.  If you write this week of wanting more I will send more.  I could send to you at Westboro I suppose. Perhaps if you are short and not time to write you can borrow of George & I will repay it when you get here.
Completed

In the last letter I sent you was a long one from Anna, which informed you of all the Elyria news better than I could.   Much Care to all.  I think you will get this letter Saturday. If you do not, I think there is no danger of your leaving Dunbarton so soon as you spoke of       Hastily   Isaac
written up left side, over other writing:
This is to be written after your fashions. It is no matter however being of any moment. I wish you had or could see some of our Apples. The sweet boughs I think are some of the finest I ever saw perfectly smooth & pressed  and many of them almost twelve inches in circumference. They are most gone now. Golden Sweets beginning to ripen some.
Completed

Elyria  Aug 13 1860

 Elyria Aug 13'60

My Dear One   Have just this evening received your letter of the 9th inst. which promised to be mailed at Concord; but was postmarked Dunbarton.  you had not then, but have doubtless ere this received my letter of the 8th enclosing X$. With this I will enclose a similar amount. Bill of our S.W. Baldwin's Home Bank of West Meriden Conn.  Will that make enough?  Fare from Worcester some $16.dollars or so.
Completed

Thermometer 91  F. on Dunbarton hills. Pretty nice that. Last Monday it was 90 (degrees) here and Tuesday 96 (degrees) ~.   We are getting along finely here.   Baby is better within a few days than she has been stoppage of her diarrhea ascribed to Mother's blackberry root tea. The boys are hearty and continually stuffing themselves with apples. Charlie eats little else.  You must excuse this scrawling letter. It is late, and I am sleepy. Got home from Session Meeting by 10 oclock, but had must to write to Eliab first.
Completed

I was amused coming in the room today - rainy day - to see a consultation between the three children: Charlie & Wilder talking very earnestly about their play as they sat on the floor, and Mary, who had scampered to them, standing on two hands & one foot, with the other foot swinging up in the air; Not a very dignified posture, but she looked as solemn as a queen rendering a judgment.   We have had a fine rain since Sabbath P.M.
Completed

Do not trouble yourself about these things. All shopping can be done here as well or better as there - to say nothing of the fact that you or Anna either have little spare money there; while your credit at least is A. 1. here.  I believe however I did promise to write you about getting a "nice fan" for Anna One costing $1.50 I believe - probably such as you could get at Wolcotts for $1.25 - "dark colors"
Completed

Cincinnati  Sept 5 1860

  Cincinnati Ohio   Sept 5 1860

My Dearest   I arrived here comfortably at 4 oclock this morning, shall stay here most of the day. And then going down the river, shall not get to DuQuoin probably till Saturday Night. So you may not hear from me after this reaches you for some days or a week or so.   I should like to know this morning how you got along with the baby last night; and
Completed

how all things pass off this Morning.   I hope you will get a girl at once. I am afraid you will tire yourself all out.  Charlie will be a good boy & do every thing he can for you when out of school.  Do not hesitate to call upon Charles for any thing he can help you about.   I am sorry not to stay longer with George, and carry him about the Country more.  Tell Charles he must do it; And not think he must stick to the
Completed

barn all the time.  Of the money I left you you will not need to keep more than $5.00 at any rate for your own expenditures. There is nothing that you can not get charged to you. I told Jen where to get Meat did I not? At Boynton's   You had better  Any Peaches to eat at any rate. And whatever you want. I shall expect to find letters for me at DuQuoin.  Be careful of yourself and children.
Completed
I am going down to Louisville on the Mail Packet McLellan at 12 N, today Sept 5  Probably stop at Louisville. part of tomorrow waiting for a boat   Isaac
Completed

Ohio River   Sept 7 1860

  Friday Sept 7 1860  New Orleans. Vicksburg & Berlin?
  Steamer Mary E. Keene  U.S. Between, Ind. & Kent'y

My Dearest   Tolerably Saturated with watching La Belle Riviere & its verdant & varying banks. I believe I must write you this Afternoon. If the writing is hardly as steady as usual you may ascribe it either to the vibrations of a fast high pressure Steamboat or to the effect of its dissipations. I wrote you a bit from Cinn. and intended to write again yesterday from Louisville, but did not get a chance. I left Cinn. at Noon Wed. on the Mail Boat Moses McLellan; reached Louisville before morning. Spent the day on
Completed

rambling the streets of that fine city, in examining the Louisville & Portland Steamboat Canal, around the falls of the Ohio and in deciding how to get down to  Cairo.   This splendid Boat, they claim the very finest on the Western Waters hardly get finished, carrying the decorations & workmen who Just the finishing touches yet on her, was just starting off her first move, on her  way to her business, which is the Bends Valley Cotton Trade. She is built expressly for that, as a companion to the Gen Quitman & the _________, the two crack boats of the Miss. River, and they claim superior to them is sundry new improvements.
Completed

This boat draws just as much water leglt?as the Ohio River Summer Steamboats when loaded down; and so goes out without any freight. The regular Ohio River Boats at this Season are little pinched up dirty things crowded with freight.  This Boat charges just double fares, and goes down full of the most aristocratic sort of passengers, Wealthy planters N.O. & Memphis Merchants who have timed their return from their Summer trip to strike this occasion. I hesitated about paying $15.00 from Louisville to Cairo; the regular fares being only 7 or 8, but I found by arrangement or somehow the only boats going
Completed

as far Cairo for a day or two were the very meanest & dirtiest imaginable. The offered to carry passengers to Cairo even for 5 or 6 dollars; but I hardly dared to go a board them and finally concluded to go the whole figure for once.  It is a regular Aristocratic Company.  Lou. & Miss Planters talking of their five or eight hundred bales, drinking high priced wines enormously, and gambling as I never saw before.   This boat runs very fast indeed where it can go; but has to spend about half the time sounding and feeling its way over the Sandbars.  So it is doubtful after all whether I get to DuQuoin by Saturday Night.
Completed

St. Charles Hotel  Cairo
Sabbath P.M.  Sept 9  1860

 Dearest   I wrote you from Cin. but failed to from Louisville; So it will  be a long time that you do not hear from me.  I scribbled a sheet Friday on the Steamboat, but there was no chance to send it sooner than to bring it along to Cairo, and mail it tomorrow.  I arrived here last night too late for the last train North, and so have to spend the Sabbath here.  Leave for DuQuoin at 4.45 tomorrow morning and get there by 9 A.M. probably.  Hope to find letter there from you awaiting for me; I am getting anxious to hear from you & the children.  This St Charles Hotel claims to be a "First Class House" and charges $2.50 per day, but in rooms, bed & table is second or third class compared with the
Completed

Mary E. Deane Steamer I came down the Ohio on, about as much difference as between ---- a really comfortable place, and one that isn't quite. I got my breakfast and sallied out this morning. I found many crowding into the Catholic Church, and a few to the Methodist, where I found a Sabbath School at the close of which the Presbyterian Minister, Rev Mr Bartlett, announced that their Church being under repairs, by the kindness of the Methodist brethren, he should preach this morning in that the Methodist house.  Between S.S. & preaching time I stepped into the Catholic Church - They are a very devout people, even more so than the Episcopalians, every one even to the children on coming in dipping the finger in the holy water, then applying it to forehead then making the sign of the Cross upon the breast, then kneeling, or taking some reverent posture.  This
Completed

This morning before the tall wax candles always burning, and surrounded with flowers & crucifixes, a priest in a clear white robe, beautifully embroidered, was preaching very fluently upon the death of the wicked, quite an orthodox discourse. Any Calvinistic Trinitarian might have used the same language, except that his frequent scriptural quotations were sometimes from the Apochrypha.  I returned to the Methodist Church in time for the service there. The S.S. had numbered about 60. The preaching audience at first was but about 30 but before the close about doubled.  The preacher was a very pleasant gentlemanly looking man, evidently of pretty good taste, but the discourse was rather commonplace.  At the close he gave notice that there could be no evening preaching, as his mind & efforts were so much engaged through the week that he was unable to prepare himself
Completed

So for the rest of the Sabbath there seems to be no motion to stem the current.  Groceries, gambling saloons, and many stores & shops I saw open on my way to Church. I suspect the devil has it pretty much all his own way here. When I think of it I am  sometimes almost sorry I did not stay, and not start till this week, on account of George. I am afraid he will have a dull visit; if you have not got any girl, and Charles is so busy about his barn. He ought to ride around the country & see that as well as the people.  Though I suppose he cares more about seeing you. Yet variety would not hurt him. You must write to me all about everything.  I can tell nothing when I get home.   Tell the boys, father says they must be good.  Kiss Baby for me   Your Own  Isaac
Completed

Du Quoin, Sept 11  1860

My Dearest    The letter which I wrote partly on the Louisville & Cairo Boat, and partly at Cairo, and mailed yesterday morning at Cairo will probably reach you two or three days earlier than this.   I arrived here about eight oclock yesterday Monday morning, and found awaiting me your letter mailed on the fifth instant, the next day after I left home and enclosing one from Eliab.  I wrote Eliab since I left Elyria, and will write again today.  But I think I will get home soon enough to attend to the business he writes about.   I mean to get home next week, perhaps early -  But cannot be at all sure yet.   I am anxious to hear from you again to know how you and the children and all get along. I suppose you had very hot weather last week - They complain of it much here.  This week is almost very cold so far.   Mr Keyes wrote me various matters - sundry deeds - and a little Money - he says last week.  The deeds can wait till I get back.   I am stopping at Keyes.  They insisted upon it, although Mrs Keyes has
Completed

just now no girl.   Their house is furnished & fixed up very nicely, comfortable & convenient. Abram Mitchell who now lives here, is building a very nice house large, brick - the finest house in Town.   The Smith's, Spragues & c. whom you remember are all well.  Mrs. Root I have not yet seen; or Mrs Wall, though I have Met Dr Wall, and Willard Wall, Now a promising young Lawyer of this place.  I must try and see the folks all round: though I have a good deal of business to attend to here, and must hasten it for Mr Keyes has to go to St Louis next week.  I think quite probable that I may get away to go home the first of next week, though it is quite uncertain.  I will write frequently   Sincerely  Your Own  Isaac
on right side:  Du Quoin  Sept 11 1860
Completed

Du Quoin  Sept 16 1860

 DuQuoin Illinois   Sabbath P.M. Sept 16 1860

My Dearest   I was a little disappointed in not getting a letter from you you last night. However perhaps the other one came so quick I could not expect another so soon.  You wrote Saturday or Sunday, and a bit Monday morning  I guessed that Charles & George went to Cleveland Monday & carried that letter; for it was Mailed at Cleveland on the Eleventh, Tuesday, and reached me here Wed. night the 12th, Was not that spry?  I have been anxious to hear again; because you wrote of Wilder' not being very well.  By the way I have been sick myself - pretty nearly.
Completed

I do not know as I ever felt better than on the boat coming down the Ohio. It was very warn you know, but it was extremely comfortable to sit in the shade, in the fresh South wind, thinly clothed dreamily feasting the eyes all day long. It seems as if the beauty of the atmosphere & scenery was drank in at every pore as well as by the eyes.   But perhaps the excessive laziness joined with the extreme high feeding was not permanently wholesome for me.  Saturday night & Sunday there was an extreme change of weather, from very warm to very cold, which last it has been since till within a day or two.  I had to stop at that most miserable Cairo over the Sabbath, and to start at 4 oclock that damp chilly Monday Morning; when I found myself with a very bad cold,  whether the effect
Completed

of the bad weather, the meanness of Cairo, the high living on the Steamboat, or simply the 4 oclock starting, (an early start, you know, never agrees with me)  I cannot tell.  The Bad Cold was quite severe but in a day or two run off into a very Diarrhea. Wednesday I was invited over to Geo Smith's to Tea with some others.  Perhaps while talking I was careless in eating pickles & cake, perhaps I caught more cold in  At any rate for two or three days I could hardly move without feeling as if everything inside of me would drop out of me.   I did not like to call upon the Doctors, and be adopted the starvation cure, but it had gone so far it took some time to starve it.  Mrs Keyes fixed up Toast Water for me to drink, a cup of Tea morning & night, & a bowl of chicken broth at Noon. It has been about as much
Completed

I wanted to do to walk over to the office (next lot) and back twice a day. And I did not get really better till last night; but today I begin to feel a good deal like myself again.  However I have managed to do a pretty good days work in the office each day; for I am in a hurry to get back again home.  This morning I still felt very quiet, and it seemed quite a walk to me over to the Church, but less coming back, and this Afternoon I call myself well.  Mr Post preached. he is the popular preacher here yet. The little Church full all the time.  His sermons do not compare very well with Mr Wilbur's; but he has always something to say, and people always like to hear him say it.  He may be more useful than Mr W. would be here.
Completed

George Smith has a fine house though built more for show than Mr Keyes   The Hall & Stairway is very fine. A very fine house to have company in, designed I guess in reference to when his five daughters go into Society. Seven children; the oldest, your old scholar Hattie is 15, about as large as her mother a pretty & accomplished young lady  fine Piano in the Parlor & c.
File:Drawing of floor plan:  entrance on left, Hall, Bed Room, Parlor, Sitting, then Dining, Kitchen &c.

 I was amused to see the Daguereotypes of four of the children in one frame, and you could not tell which was oldest or youngest.  Aunt Sally, Mrs Root, was there just the same as ever. She and her Ann. I guess are rather looked up to by all here.   Ellen Wall, you remember, another
Completed

of your old scholars, is to be married in a few weeks to Edward Ross. You remember him I guess, handsome chubby faced boy; and his sister like him, Abby Ross from Vergennes or Tuttle's Prairie. And Abby Ross is to be married at the same time to young Dyer, Son of Dr Dyer. Dr Wall's partner in business.   G. Willard Wall, the promising young lawyer, "the most promising young man in this part of the state", by courting or pretending to court the daughter of Old Nettleton, the Catholic Merchant.   Abram Mitchell is building a large brick house here; will be the largest & finest house in Town.  The great Public Square or Park is fenced with a fine black fence wood, but looks like iron though heavy
Completed

They take now of moving the County Seat here, & building the Court House in the Middle of the Sq. It will very likely be sometime. Mr Keyes has got lots of choice plants & shrubbery growing and started around his lot; a great many things that will not grow farther North I suppose. Some however that I mean to get seeds of to carry home. As every where South there is excess of climbing plants; which you know are scarce with us.   One I will bring home seeds of: a Morning glory leaf with Cypress vine flowers.  There are Morning Glories here
Completed

flowers four inches across. That Fringe Tree which you remember is the yard at the Old Town, is said now to be the finest in the Country, very much larger fuller and finer than it used to be. And I do not know as I ever saw its superior years ago.   The fact is Nettie you ought to visit DuQuoin. You must Sometime.  I hope to get a letter from you tomorrow night.  I mean to get home by the End of this week.   Truly  Isaac
Completed

Columbus Ohio  Oct. 1861
on side:  Columbus  Oct. 10 '61

Dearest   Pleasant trip so far.  Did not leave Grafton till 3.20. Reach here 7.45.  Leave here  12 P.M.   Reach Cincinnatil 5. A.M.  Probably Leave Cincinnati 7.30   11.05  Reach Centralia perhaps 9 P.M.   I am a little afraid you may be bothered by Township Trustee's Pauper folks. You can send then over to Esquire Paddock. I urgent case give an Order for Lodging at Erne's.  But I guess you will not be troubled. Folks down Town know I am away.  If there comes Frost, tell Charlie to gather the Summer Squashes to give the Cows. Also if the Frost is hard the Tomatoes, and the few Hubbard Squashes in the garden. Or cover them up perhaps
Completed

I told Charlie not to have the Horse harnessed at all. If you want on Sabbath or any other time you can get Mr Waldo's. It is hardly safe for Charlie to drive or use Old Mary now she has not be used for so long.   You had better pick those Catawba Grapes on the Trellis, when you have time, at least if there comes frost. If you do not let Mr Finn or some one have those grapes. You had better make three or four pans full of Juice.  You know there are two pans full under the bed in front Chamber. Those with the Catawba's are enough to save to eat. Perhaps it would be good to put them in the Tank, as you proposed.  Let Gertrude pick the Lima Beans, before Frost Comes, and Charlie dispose of the vines.  There is abundant work for him to do in the Garden, if he wants Saturdays, or other.   "Twould be well for him to hoe over
Completed

his Corn field.   He will take good care of every thing I guess, when he feels the responsibility.   Tell the boys to be very good.   I should like to kiss Little May tonight  Write me if Mother goes to Sandusky, and for how long.   Sincerely  Isaac
Completed

Cincinnati Ohio  Oct 11. 1861

 My Dearest   I arrived here all right this Morning, but found the only through Train on Ohio & Miss R.R. was the Evening Train at 5 P.M.  The Morning going no farther than Seymore, or to Louisville Ky, where I do not care to go.  So I stay in Cinn. all day 12 hours.  Ride about the Streets & c.  leave at 5. P.M.  Centralia the next Morning.  DuQuoin  probably at Noon.  Write this to keep you advised    Love & c.   Isaac   P.M.
Completed

DuQuoin, Perry Co Illinois
Sabbath  Oct. 13. 1861

 Dearest & Very Nettie   I wrote a few lines to you from Columbus, & again from Cincinnati And again at Odin, where on the Ohio & Mississippi R.R. I reached the Illinois Central, and had a little while to wait. I wrote again just to tell you I had got safely over the unfortunate O. & M. R.R. but I did not quite get a chance to mail it  , and after I got away from there it was no use to mail it till Monday Morning   I staid in Cincinnati all day Friday. left at 5 P.M.  There were two accidents on the Road that day, the debris and disorder of which hindered us some so that instead of reaching the Ill. Central at 5 A.M. it was near 8.  From there waiting along by a a Freight Train.  I finally reached here at 2 P.M.  People here are very well, and as every where else talking only of the war  Mr & Mrs Keyes take their Meals at the Hotel across the street, and in their nice house, without the trouble of housekeeping appear very comfortable  I was as  Mr Abram Mitchell's last evening.  His is now rather the finest house in Town, but I guess they
Completed

they live rather plainly, as their taste doubtless is.   Today have been at Church & heard Mr Post, of whom you remember. He is however about to stop preaching here.  you remember perhaps hearing he lost his wife - last winter, was it - He is married again - a Ross girl, formerly of Vergennes.   After Meeting  by urgent invitation  Went to Dr Walls to Dinner.  Dr W's health much better than it used to be.  A partner to do the hard business.  Mr. W not very well I guess every time, but just as she used to be. And like the rest of the old folks very anxious to see you out here.   Ellen, do you remember married to Ed Ross, lives now at Pulaski, near Cairo.  G. Willard a thriving young Lawyer of this ilk lives at home.  Quite a promising young man.  DuQuoin improves some in spite of the times. Streets being graded , Shade trees set out & growing in Park & along streets, & c.   DuQuoin is handsomer, and more prosperous than any of the other  Villages along the R.Road. At least it seems so to me.   The war is the great thing here though. Mr Pease is Col Pease is Commissioned, and raising a
Completed

Regiment for the War.   Seely, I do not know as you remember him, my Centralia Carpenter, is Major in a Cavalry Regiment.  Harry Given is raising Cavalry.  His younger brother, who came out here about the time you left, and has been with him on R.R.ds here has died this Summer.  L. Bradford Skinner, you remember who was with us & since of Geo. S. Smith &Co. has gone in a Cavalry Regiment and a younger brother also. In the 18 ILL. now in Missouri.  Dr Burgess, one of the oldest Physicians here, came here about the time you left, is Lieut Col. & Sam Eaton, who was with me the 1st year I was here, is Major.  Perhaps you remember a large lot of the Old folks about the Station here, went off to Missouri about the time we began the Village here.  Pyles, Drys McGrains, Atkins &c among the rest the Atkins we bought this farm of where the Village now is.  They are all driven off, burnt out, striped of every thing, lost all they possess. Except two who turned Secesh. Teague who was killed at Wilson's Creek, and Fannin who is still Officer in Rebel Army.   Well I want to hear from you
Completed

How you all do & be.   How Charley get along with all the things &c. &c. &c. &c. &c. &c. &c.  Whether there is any Frost there  There has been Frost every where between there & here. A very little even here.  Oh it is most splendid weather here now. The Regular Egyptian October weather, the ? in the year, and the finest in the World. By the way this is a little the finest climate in the world, it not?  Do you not wish you lived here?  Almost I do some times.  Write me as soon as you get this, and perhaps I will come home as soon, as I get that letter of yours    Sincerely   Your  Isaac
Completed

DuQuoin  Oct 16 1861

  DuQuoin ILL  Oct 16  '61

My Dearest   Too dark to see, so I write you a minute.   Very Well  Very busy   No letters from home yet.   Monday took tea at Mitchells  Tuesday P.M. with Keyes to Elk Prairie, about Smith, Keyes & McNally land.  Rode 20 Miles.  Today spent a hour or two underground in Coal Mine  All very first rate
Completed

Rather think now I will go to Chicago early next week.  Home last thereof.   Want to hear from you.  Love & Kisses  for ? & Children  Suppose Mother is gone to Perkins this Week?  Take Care of Yourself as well as the others   Your Isaac
Completed

Mattoon   Oct. 16 1862

  Mattoon ILL. Thurs 16 Oct '62  1 P.M.

Dearest   All very well so far, wait nearly an hour at Grafton?   Two hours at Crestline slept well to Indianapolis  7 A.M.  Crowds - crowds of Soldiers volunteers. Drafted. Sick discharged, furloughed &c. &c.  Indianapolis even more than Columbus is a great Camp.  More soldiers, and more in the City. At Columbus the Camp is a little away from the City - you know.  Arrive here at 1 P.M.  But delays by the way will prevent my getting to DuQuoin before Midnight I suppose
Completed

Please take good care of yourself and not get tired & sick.  I left some directions for Charlie.  There are some Pears on two trees in the Garden.  Winkfields & Angouleme that ought to be picked before it freezes much.   I do not believe it will freeze to hurt the grapes.  The little boys better pick up the apples as they fall.  Apples down cellar should be looked at.  I forget whether I told Mr Waldo where to put Potatoes - in a Bbl under Apples.  If Darling hauls Manure there he must put it on the S.W. Part where
Completed

the 'Crops' are W.  I guess he will not haul any till I get home.  I forgot to set Gertrude to cleaning thoroughly that Sorghum Cask. Must be done before it is filled.   Take care of self  Kiss little folks for me    Sincerely  I.S.
Completed

DuQuoin  Oct 17 1862

 DuQuoin Oct 17 1862

Dearest   Arrived here safely at One oclock this morning.  Mr Keyes at Chicago but home today Noon.  Business of all sorts very brisk here, as good if not better than ever before. Great demand for Coal, but great difficulty of getting labor to get it with.  People all pretty well as usual.  Some Ague on acc't of rainy Autumn   Mrs Hall & Mrs Ben Sprague they say have it some. The Keyes Book they say is out. Shall I
Completed

Shall I bring home a copy.   Could you read my Pencil scrawl from Mattoon?   Wish I could hear from you every day or so   I mean to stay here only next week  or at least get home by Middle of week after.    Sincerely   Isaac
Completed

DuQuoin  Oct 19 1862

 DuQuoin Oct 19 1862  Sabbath Eve

My Dearest   I must write a little this evening. I have not much to write.  Beautiful Weather! Beautiful exceedingly the weather! As only Southern Illinois weather it seems can be  The air is perfectly clear, the atmosphere balmy, the wind whispers so softly over the prairie. It is a most delightful climate - sometimes at least - and a most splendid Country too! so much broader and wider and higher than Ohio.  Way it expands and stretches out all around you; you ca see as far as you can see every way and way up into the air too.  Is not it a little strange that any one will live there in Ohio, so pinched up among the trees, unable to see out
Completed

when there is such a country as this - all right out doors too!  Really & seriously though, does it seem natural that any one who has ever seen a Prairie should ever fell contended among the trees on a flat plain, where there is no seeing out even?  Thursday, Friday & Saturday were very warm, clear bright warm days, almost too warm for a Cloth Coat. Today is just as clear & bright, as they, or as day can be, and less breeze, but cool almost cold, so that one likes to walk fast, and the bright coal fires feel as well as look inviting.   They have no preaching here now. Mr Post left near a year ago. Old Mr Lippinscott from the Old Town preached  here half the time for Six Months.
Completed

Then a Mr. McHickey from Chicago preached here some, and they rented the slips and got a Subscription to raise $600.00 a year to hire him the whole time, but he had a call east, and it fell through, and many of them have gone to the war, and they have no Minister. And to day - at the Deacon Meeting, Geo Smith presiding, a stranger named Metcalf was called upon a read a sermon of Alexander Cummings. Mrs. Benj. Sprague's sick and their folks were not at Meeting, Mrs. Dr. Wall is sick and their folks were not at Meeting. The rest, the Smiths, the Roots, the Spragues' were there & glad to see.

 By special invitation, at the Special solicitation of John Aloah Spragues' wife's Mother, old Mrs. Chandler, I went with them to Dinner. The Old Lady remembered you were at DuQuoin, Where
Completed

she was visiting before John Sprague went back to New York.
She lives now at Fulton, is down here on a visit. Where she says young Cogswell's reputation is bad. Very particular in inquiries after the Bradford's & Browns. Is she a sister of old Mrs. Bradford.
Forenoon Audience about 50
Sabbath School at 3 P.M. a hundred 
Has been 150 through the Summer.
No evening meeting
Hiram Hinckley died about a month ago. His Son George like most of the young men about here is in the Army. Ill. 6th Car. at Memphis with Brad & Ayg. Skinner & Ben Guiteau. Guy C. Ward, on of the most valuable young men of this village, Capt. in Il.. 18th killed at Corinth, was brought home a day or two since. Five from here were killed there.
Completed

Major Eaton; Sam Eaton. perhaps you remember, used to be with me was killed at Pittsburgh Landing; as was also George Mitchell. Abram Mitchell has bought ten acres N.E. of Town which he is starting peach orchards here 3 or 4 years planted have paid this year $1000.00 clear. If I can bring it about I mean to have my 16 acre tract joining town set in Peach trees this fall or next spring.  By the way you remember, or hearing of, E.P. Pettis & Brother, formerly "Pettis & Chickering of St Louis, used to be my agents, purchased &c. &c. E.P. is here now with his family, Brothers family expect to come in Spring; they have purchased each 60 acres N.E. of Town, the rest of thePyle tract extending from the Wall tract, now partly part of the village right North
Completed

of the original village, extending from this Wall tract east to my 40 acre tracts in Sec. 9, Mile from the village centre. This you know is my 40 acres which I want to live on, and Pettis speaks of it as the very finest situation he knows of. It is splendid place for a place; Little hill in Grove overlooking the prairie and village. If we only lived there we could see out you know.

 Mrs. Keyes is going to Ohio to spend the winter with her Mother who is sick. The Pettis family are to occupy the Keyes house. Mr. Keyes living at the Hotel where he has taken his Meals for a year or two.
 his Keyes Book -

Monday morning  First Frost
of the Season
Completed

DuQuoin
Oct. 26 1862

                                                                                                       Du Quoin Oct. 26 1862

Very Dearest

  No letter from you in all this time, and how I have wanted to hear from you all at home. I have written three times, once on the way here, once as soon as I reached here, and again last Sabbath Afternoon or evening. Since then I have been exceedingly busy; I think I have done a very great weeks work. I have been all over all the accounts of Keyes & Metcalf, arranging and making up everything for a full settlement. There has never been a full settlement or full reckoning up of the our partnership affairs for the whole nine years. And I have felt a good deal anxious about it for a good while. If either of us had been were taken away, our matters would have been perfectly inextricable. Neither Bookkeepers nor Lawyers could have made a proper settlement. But the whole matter has got a going over now I can assure you. I shall have some credits left in the concern too. But I have worked hard the past week. My health is very good. My back doubled in strength almost by the time I got here, and my cold, which I had for a week or two before I left was all gone soon after I got back; and now I do not know as I ever was better or stronger. And yet this confinement, constrains writing and thinking does not agree with me. My brains are not the best part of me, I guess, and the constant use of them does not agree with me. Instead of dropping asleep the moment my head touches the pillow and sleeping every chance I can get. I can not
Completed

get asleep or sleep half the night; but feel more like getting up, and going to work upon some knotty point or columns of figures. However perhaps it is only because I try to sleep too much, And I certainly eat, drink, and work admirably.

 It has been most splendidly beautifully weather all the past week. - almost. Last Monday Morning was the first frost of the season -  not very severe, but the day was exceeding fine, and so were 4 which succeeded it. Friday though the wind blew, the prairie wind, the west wind, what is it that Hiawatha calls it. At night it clouded up. Saturday morning it snowed finely, and what is more wonderfull continued till Afternoon, and then grew cold so that this Sabbath Morning it was quite crisp. a really winter morning for this country, and quite a wonder to the oldest inhabitants. 

But it is all gone now and there may be no more frost for weeks.  I have been almost worrying about it today, fearing if this kind of weather extends to Northern Ohio. that you may not be comfortable - for fires,  and wood piles etc. The Grapes etc. may suffer but that is of less consequence. I am afraid you and Mother may tire & worry your selves in trying to save them.

  Business here is better, and every thing here getting on better than I feared before I left home.

The Coal Business is bound to amount to something I am well convinced. It did really  and bona fide pay me - for my share. over a thousand dollars ($1,000.00) last winter. that of it  I have not received, I shall receive.
Completed

First of April the Miners struck you know, and there was no work done for the entire month. while of course there must be some expense all the time. Machinery must be kept running to keep the mine clear of water etc. Then the trade broken in upon, and disarranged by a months stoppage, the next month May would be but half of anything and no profit. Then the Superintendent went into the Army, ~ and the Foreman or Head Miner - and the Engineer, and the Clerk - and the Miners. And every thing was so broken up they did not get fairly to work again till the first of September, and made only a half a full months work in September.  And yet the result is not neat as bad as I anticipated, as I expected before I got here. Really I believe when we get it all reckoned up - through a part of  the sort of interregnum the Books were not kept up, accounts settled, or bills collected, and it is considerable work to straighten matters. I begin to believe it will be found that the whole time from April 1 to Sept 1 the Mine nearly or quite covered expenses.

 And now the prospect for Winters work is very fine. I shall be disappointed, if there is no special bad luck, if my share of the profits does not amount to twice as much as last winter.  
 When shall I get home?

When I left home -realizing that it was a bad time of year to be absent longer, I wanted to get home Saturday, is yesterday, and rather thought I could by next Wednesday 19th, at farthest. There is a Corporation School meeting then that I wanted to be at too.
But this settlement was imperative; it had ?
Completed

? these two years, it had been put off, far too long. I found I could get Mr. Keyes at it. It would not do to defer it. So I made up my mind to stay,  and have it out at any rate, and you would get along somehow at home.  I hope now to get through, and get home in the course of the week, but make no promises, and you need not expect me  till you see me arrive. But I do want to hear from you all; And wonder I did not last week. I did not have to read a sermon this forenoon there was a minister there to preach,  and is to be again this Evening. But the Attendance is small. some are gone to the war, and some are sick. I told you of Capt. G. C. Ward brought home killed at Corinth dead a week or two since. Mrs. Dr. Wall & Mrs. Dea Ben Sprague are sick, and so is Mr. Merchant Hatch, the S.S. Superintendent, which institution languishes for his lack. Do you remember Young Ross, (not Ellen Wall's Ross, they live now down at Villa Ridge or South Pass) but the one who was the Clerk for Milford Hinkley, son of old Man Ross out on the Prairie near old Clarks'. His young wife died in Child bed a few days ago. Several deaths thus about here within a few weeks. Mrs Abram Mitchell about to be confined is reported very anxious and nervous on that score.
Trade revives here now. Prices high. Geo. & Ed. Smith, like the other Traders, of whom they stand at the head, getting rich.
Benj. Guitteau & Brad. Skinner distinguishing themselves in the Ill. C. Cavalry, Also 4 sons of Old Clark in the same Company.
The "Things" you remember -are Spiritualists, Mrs Damon Thing a Medium. 

                                                                 Well Love &c.
                                                                                      Isaac

Mrs. I.S. Metcalf Elyria Ohio                                                                  I.S. Metcalf Elyria Ohio
Completed

Sandusky
Jan. 27 1863

                                                                                                             Sandusky Jan. 27 '63
                                                                                                              West House

Dearest

       Arrived here at 12 PM. Wait till 5 P.M. Then to Monroeville 15 Miles, then with evening Train from Cleveland & Toledo, and by Wabash Valley to Illinois.
  Quite a storm today, not so much snow here; but quite a prospect of Cold I think.
I want you should write to me, no matter if only a few words, if you have time for no more, as often, or oftener as every other day, for the present at least: till better mother & me can feel better about the children.

You know I shall feel very anxious
Completed

now till I hear from you.
I guess you will get along. If the weather continues as it has been this month past you like every body else may be troubled for wood. But I guess Mr. Waldo will look after it in some shape.

 One think I forgot to mention to Mr. Waldo: John Lane is coming when there is fair Weather to put up Eave Troughs at the Barn, and Mr. Waldo will be wanted fix & box up the water conductor where it goes in the cistern, to protect it. But Charley, or perhaps Lane can speak to Waldo about it. 

Charley Rich will see to every thing well I guess.
Do no heart? for you & Mother
Completed

to ask him about it occasionally. - Do keep watch of the slop Barrell - Do keep the gates fast shut, and the Cattle out of the Garden- Do take good care of the animals, and not waste the hay. The horse will need no Oats, give her her feed of Corn every day, and carrots, and turn her out with the Colts every pleasant day. She will not need to be harnessed while I am gone, without Dr. DeWitt wants her, or you want and can trust Charley to drive her to Church or somewhere.
Please put Charley in mind - if there should be cold weather - to look
Completed

out - that all the animals get a good chance for water.
Finally - you and Mother take good care of your selves - not tired out or make your selves sick.
And write to me

                              Sincerely
                                        Isaac
Completed

Chicago
Jan. 28 1863

                                                                           Adams House Chicago
                                                                                      Jan. 28 1863

Dearest

         Arriving at Toledo an hour last night, found the Wabash Train which I intended to take had gone  - did not wait for the delayed Cleveland Train. So I transferred myself instead to the N.S. & N. I.R.R. Train for Chicago. Had a good nights rest -- for 12 P.M. to 8 A.M. and duly arrived at Chicago, before noon.

No snow at all here, or for a hundred miles east of here. Here today the weather is delightful. Clear, bright & bracing; just barely cool enough to keep the ground froze, and roads good.
Completed

I found today DeWitt C. Rowley and Charles H. Thaxter together with Clinton Furbish & Co. at 24 River St. Chicago. Produce Commission Business. Both appeared very glad to see me, and wanted me to stop & go out to see their folks; Rowley lives at Waukegan, Thaxter at Cleaverville 5 or 6 miles out.
Rowley has been to Pikes Peak, and spent a year or so at Warren Ohio in the Oil Region, Oil Well, business, besides doing almost every thing (I guess in his beloved 'Chicago!
No person in the world he would give more to see than you, Nettie.

 He may be a better man than Thaxter; but is not so much of a Man, as Thaxter. I guess
Completed

I shall go South on the Night Train tonight, 8.45 P.M. I believe it is. And probably get to Du Quoin sometime tomorrow. And remain anxious to hear from you and the Children.

                                                     Isaac S.M.
Completed

Du Quoin
Jan 29 1863

                                                                                                             Illinois
                                                                                                             Du Quoin Perry Co
                                                                                                             Jan. 29 1863

Dearest

                    Arrived here in good condition about Noon today.

Mr. Keyes absent at Springfield Mrs. Keyes still here living and boarding in rooms at the Public House, another family in their house, which makes it not quite so pleasant for me.
Mining business apparently prosperous. Miners making about almost a dollar an hour while they work
Proprietors ought to make something!
Completed

Ghetty Keyes is at work regularly in the Mine, as as "Trapper". Took a notion to -- and so of course does. 11 years old, little bigger than Wilder & Charley. 50 cts per day! I do not know what will become of the boy!

 Dr. Wall laid up with bruises obtained leaping off the cars.

Abram Mitchell another child, girl, two months old. Jake Mitchell ditto.

 General ? of health
